page.title: 18CRUMMOCK : OLD OAK WOOD.
page.content: Bordering Crummock Water is an ancient oak wood divided into the Greenwood and Flasswood.It is centuries old and nearing the end of it's natural life span.The wood is privately owned and is preserved for it's ornithological value.During 3 months of 1985 the following birds were observed in the wood.Resident birds included Blue tit,Great tit, Wren, Tawny Owl,Kestrel Great Spotted Woodpecker,Green Woodpecker,Tree Creeper,Jay,Song Thrush,Wood Pigeon,Stonechat,Goldcrest Yellowhammer,Magpie,Jackdaw,Robin and Blackbird.Visiting birds included Pied Flycatcher,Cuckoo,Yellow and Grey Wagtails and Ring Ouzel.Peregrine Falcons nest in the hills around Crummock.These are a protected species and the valuable eggs are guarded by volunteer wardens.
